page.title: 16THE SPALDING SEWAGE WORKS
page.content: The works were opened in 1980 at a cost of Â£5.3m. The works were built here because of the closeness of the industrial area and the River Wellend into which the treated water is pumped. They receive a lot of effluent from Smedleys and British Sugar for treatment. The sewage gets to the works by a series of gravity sewers and pumping mains. This network of pipes is laid underground all over Spalding. Because of the flat nature of the area 63 pumping stations are used to convey the sewage along the pipes to the treatment works. The works receive about 1,320,000 gallons of sewage a day but during periods of heavy rain fall this may increase to 3,300,000 gallons. The works treat sewage from Spalding Town and Pinchbeck Village.
